Toynbee To Lecture Nina Simone Slated To Appear
On Uniqueness Topic At Shriver Hall Jazz Concert'
Arnold Toynbee, renowned
British historian, will give
an address entitled "The
Question of Uniqueness,"
Monday afternoon at 4 P.M.
in Shriver Hall.

eluding The Nation, Asia Contemporary Revie w, Atlantic
Monthly, and New Republic.
Toynbee was professor of
Byzantine and modern Greek
history at the University of
London.

Sponsored by the Council of
Religious Groups as a part of
Brotherhood Week, Toynbee's
lecture will concern the claims
Of uniqueness made by Judaisni,
Christianity and Islam.
Recently in Montreal, Toynbee
delivered a series of lectures on
the Israeli-Arab conflict. As a
result of the lectures he became
involved in some debates with
rabbis concerning his views, and
was termed anti-semitic by Reinhold Niebuhr.
Educated at Winchester College and Oxford University in
England, Toynbee is the author
of the ten volume work Study of
History.
He is also a frequent contributor to scholarly publications in-

ARNOLD TOYNBEE

Whit Nruis
VOL. LXV, No. 15

Popular jazz songstress,
Nina Simone, will appear in
the jazz concert at Shriver
Hall next Tuesday night at
8:30 p.m.
The concert will be one of the
programs in the observation of
Brotherhood Week which is
sponsored by the Hopkins YMCA.
Miss Simone, who has been
characterized as "an extremely
winning performer," studied at
the Julliard School of Music before turning to jazz singing.
Widely Acclaimed
Her concerts at other colleges
and universities, widely acclaimed
by the press, have proved very
popular.
The New York Times once
noted, "Miss Simone has enough
voice, enough pianistic skill and
a sufficiently keen sense of showmanship to carry off what
amounts to a three-ring circus
with a disarmingly casual air."

Musical Sensation
The Detroit Free Press acclaimed her "the only musical
sensation" at a three-day- jazz
festival held at the State Fairgrounds in the Motor City last
summer.
And the New York Citizen-Call
stated that "it is unusual indeed
in these days of electronic magic
to find a singer who sounds even
better in person than she does
on record. Such is Nine Simone."
Has Class
According to Langston Hughes,
noted jazz critic, Miss Simone
"has class, but does not wear it
on her shoulders. She is unique.
You either like her or you don't.
If you don't, you won't. If you
do—whee—ouuu-ou! You do!"
Prior to the concert a dinner
will be given for Miss Simone
where she will meet various student leaders.
Tickets for the concert are
available in the Y office

In a statement Dr. W. K.
Morrill, Dean of Students, said:
"We all realize the need in the
world today for a spirit of
brotherhood. One way that we
at Hopkins can demonstrate our
concern is through Brotherhood
Week. This, however, is only the
beginning. If we are genuinely
concerned, we will live brotherhood the year 'round."
Dr. Wickwire also stated that:
"A brotherhood week may be
nothing more than a gesture
and perhaps even an excuse for
inaction and the neglect of human relations the rest of the
year. There is also the possibility that this week will be a time
to determine the nature of responsible citizenship.

After Research

Dr. Clement L. Markert, professor of biology at The Johns
Hopkins University, returned to
his duties at the Homewood
Campus this week after completing a six-month embryology
study in Naples, Italy.
Dr. Markert, took a six-month
leave of absence to study at the
Stazione Zoological Marine
Laboratory in Naples.
Terming his expe rime nts
"highly successful," Dr. Markert
used the "Sea Squirt" as his experimental animal. "This unique specie of marine life is extremely useful in studying the
embryo phenomenon," Dr. Markert reported.
He said the "Sea Squirt,"
which develops from the single
egg cell into adulthood within a
24-hour period, is abundant in
the waters off the coast of
Naples.

"A GUIDE FOR THE DATELESS"
With the cost of dating rising higher and higher it is no wonder
that so many of us men are turning to discus throwing. Naturally, we would prefer nuzzling warm coeds to flinging cold
disci, but who's got that kind of money? Prices being what they
are,the average man today has a simple choice: dating or eating.
Unless the average man happens to be Finster Sigafoos.
Finster came to college with the normal ambition of any
average man: he wanted to find the prettiest coed on campus
and make her his. He looked long and carefully, and at last he
found her—a tall job named Kretchma Inskip, with hair like
beaten gold.
He asked her for a date. She accepted. He appeared at her
sorority house that night,smiling, eager, and carrying a bouquet
of modestly priced flowers.
"Now then," said Kretchma, tossing the sleazy flora to a
pledge, "where are we going tonight?"
Finster was a man short on cash, but long on ideas. He had
prepared an attractive plan for this evening. "How would you
like to go out to the Ag campus and see the milking machine?",
he asked.
"Ick," she replied.
"Well, what would you like to do?" he asked.
"Come," said she,"to a funny little place I know just outside
of town."
And away they went.

Is your future up in the air?
As the communications needs of our nation
become steadily greater and more complex,
the Bell Telephone System is continuing its
pioneer work in microwave by "taking to the
air" more and more to get the word across.
To this end, Western Electric—the manufacturing arm of the Bell System—has the
monumental task of producing a large part of
the microwave transmission equipment that
knits our country together by shrinking thousands of miles into mere seconds.
In spite of its great technological strides,
the science of radio relay is a rapidly-changing
one. And new brehk-throughs and advances
are common occurrences. A case in point: our
Bell System "TH" Microwave Radio Relay.
This newest development in long-distance
telephone transmission will eventually triple
the present message-carrying capacity of existing long-haul radio relay installations. A fullscale system of 6 working and 2 protection
channels can handle 11,000 telephone messages at the same time.
To make microwave work takes a host of
special equipment and components: relay
towers, antennae, waveguides, traveling wavetubes, transistors, etc. But just as important,

it takes top-caliber people to help us broaden
our horizons into such exciting new areas as
communication by satellites!
And microwave is only part of Western
Electric's opportunity story. We have—right
now—hundreds of challenging and rewarding
positions in virtually all areas of telephony,
as well as in development and building of
defense communications and missile guidance
systems .for the Government.
So, if your future is "up in the air," you owe
it to your career to see "what's up" for you at
Western Electric.
Opportunities exist for electrical, mechanical, industrial, civil and chemical engineers, as well as physical
science, liberal arts, and business majors. For more
information, get your copy of "Western Electric and
Your Career" from your Placement Officer. Or write
College Relations, Room 6106, Western Electric Company, 195 Broadway, New York 7, N. Y. And be sure
to arrange for a Western Electric interview when the
Bell System recruiting team visits your campus.

Goucher Offers
Three Lectures
About Radiation
A series of lectures on radiation and its effects are currently being given at Goucher College.

Landman will deliver a talk on
"The Effect of Radiation on
Genes." Dr. Landman is affiliated with the Medical Bacteriology Division of the Army
Chemical Center. The talk will
be held in Mary Fisher Lounge
at 1:30 .p.m.
"The
Use
of
Radioactive
Isotopes in Research" will be the
subject of a talk given by Dr.
Hugh Miller of the Atomic
Energy Commission. Dr. Miller
will speak in Mary Fisher
Lounge on February 26 at 1:30
p.m.
The final lecture in the series
will take place in Anna Heubeck
Lounge on March 3 at 7:00 p.m.
Dr. William L. Neumann of the
Goucher History Department will
discuss "The Military and Strategic Significance of Nuclear
Energy."

President Out of Touch
That Dr. Eisenhower, himself,
Is out of touch with the student
body, is quite evident from his
recently published report on the
University. Filled with reuttered
self praise and past glory, it presented a picture wholly foreign
to the University of the undergraduate. His proposal for dormitory advisors .was an unrealistic proposal in view of our past
experiences with them. Advisors
provide little direction, from our
experience; and the type of direction they offer is usually the
kind which the undergraduate
tries to avoid.
Rather than additional advisors or more stringent student
regulations, this undergraduate
body needs direction and organization on the levels on which
it can be satisfied. It craves
recognition in a scholar-laden
environment which seems only
to ignore it. It wants a Dr.
Morrill who can offer a challenging and inspiring program of
student activities in the nature
of the highly popular Baltimore
Symphony concerts and some of
the Levering sponsored events.
It wants a faculty willing to
offer, a varied course schedule
with more inspirational lectures.
It wants school pride and spirit
which seems suppressed everywhere.

McCollum Gains
Medicine Medal
For Research
Dr. Elmer McCollum, discoverer of Vitamin A and professor
emeritus of Bio-Chemistry at The
Johns Hopkins University, has
received the New York Academy
of Medicine Medal for his basic
research and contributions in
the field of nutrition.
The noted Hopkins biochemist's accomplishments also include the discovery of vitamin
131 and vitamin D. He is also a
founder of the Johns Hopkins
McCollum-Pratt Institute.
Dr. McCollum's latest honor
reads in part: "In recognition of
his basic research which ushered
in the era of the newer knowledge of nutrition; of his fruitful
efforts which contributed to the
eradication of deficiency diseases; of his demonstration of
the tremendous significance of
nutrition ... for the promotion
Of health and prolongation of
life; and his inflluence upon
dietary habits of man throughout the world, writing and teaching.
"
Dr. McCollum is only the 15th
Than to receive the medical medal since its formation 32 years
ago.

Geophysical Union
Names Pritchard
To Presidency
Dr. Donald W. Pritchard, director of the Chesapeake Bay
Institute of The Johns Hopkins
University, has been named
president of the American Geophysical Union. Dr. Pritchard is
scheduled to take office July 1,
and will remain in the post for
three years.
The AGU will hold its 13th
general assembly of the International Union of Geodesy and
Geophysics in Berkeley, Caliiornia, in August.
Dr. Pritchard is presently
Conducting studies of the dispersal and movement of nuclear
waste products in estuarine and
coastal environments. He has
also conducted work in the past
on the dynamics of estuarine
circulation.
He received his bachelor of
science degree in meterology at
the University of California in
1942. He received his master's
degree in Oceanography from
of
the Scripps Institution
Oceanography in 1948 and completed his doctoral degree at the
Scripps Institute in 1952. He
joined the Johns Hopkins University faculty in 1953.

CONTROL SYSTEMS:
ORDERS FROM A COMPUTER
NOW CONTROL
GIANT OIL REFINERY UNIT

Every 24 hours, the world's largest distillation unit separates
crude oil into ten different categories which end up as six
million gallons of finished products.
This involves continual monitoring of 196 instruments, followed by precise balancing of controls. To operate at peak
efficiency, control directions are changed seventy-two times
daily to compensate for a multitude of variables.
The IBM computer that recently took over this job now reads
the instruments, makes the calculations, and issues the
orders for the control changes. It is guided in its work by
75,000 instructions stored in its electronic memory.
Just a few years ago electronic control of such a complex

industrial process would have been impossible. But such is
the progress in computer systems that in the sixties it will
become commonplace.
This dramatic progress means exciting and important jobs
at IBM for the college graduate, whether in research, development, manufacturing, or programming.
If you want to find out about opportunities in any one of these
areas, you are invited to talk with the IBM representative. He
will be interviewing on your campus this year. Your placement
office can make an appointment. Or write, outlining your
background and interests, to: Mgr. of Technical Employment,
Dept. 898, IBM Corp., 590 Madison Ave., New York 22, N. Y,

IBM

Arnold Toynbee, renowned
British historian, will give
an address entitled "The
Question of Uniqueness,"
Monday afternoon at 4 P.M.
in Shriver Hall.

eluding The Nation, Asia Contemporary Revie w, Atlantic
Monthly, and New Republic.
Toynbee was professor of
Byzantine and modern Greek
history at the University of
London.

Sponsored by the Council of
Religious Groups as a part of
Brotherhood Week, Toynbee's
lecture will concern the claims
Of uniqueness made by Judaisni,
Christianity and Islam.
Recently in Montreal, Toynbee
delivered a series of lectures on
the Israeli-Arab conflict. As a
result of the lectures he became
involved in some debates with
rabbis concerning his views, and
was termed anti-semitic by Reinhold Niebuhr.
Educated at Winchester College and Oxford University in
England, Toynbee is the author
of the ten volume work Study of
History.

Widely Acclaimed
Her concerts at other colleges
and universities, widely acclaimed
by the press, have proved very
popular.
The New York Times once
noted, "Miss Simone has enough
voice, enough pianistic skill and
a sufficiently keen sense of showmanship to carry off what
amounts to a three-ring circus
with a disarmingly casual air."

Musical Sensation
The Detroit Free Press acclaimed her "the only musical
sensation" at a three-day- jazz
festival held at the State Fairgrounds in the Motor City last
summer.
And the New York Citizen-Call
stated that "it is unusual indeed
in these days of electronic magic
to find a singer who sounds even
better in person than she does
on record. Such is Nine Simone."
Has Class
According to Langston Hughes,
noted jazz critic, Miss Simone
"has class, but does not wear it
on her shoulders. She is unique.
You either like her or you don't.
If you don't, you won't. If you
do—whee—ouuu-ou! You do!"
Prior to the concert a dinner
will be given for Miss Simone
where she will meet various student leaders.
Tickets for the concert are
available in the Y office

After Research

Dr. Clement L. Markert, professor of biology at The Johns
Hopkins University, returned to
his duties at the Homewood
Campus this week after completing a six-month embryology
study in Naples, Italy.
Dr. Markert, took a six-month
leave of absence to study at the
Stazione Zoological Marine
Laboratory in Naples.
Terming his expe rime nts
"highly successful," Dr. Markert
used the "Sea Squirt" as his experimental animal. "This unique specie of marine life is extremely useful in studying the
embryo phenomenon," Dr. Markert reported.
He said the "Sea Squirt,"
which develops from the single
egg cell into adulthood within a
24-hour period, is abundant in
the waters off the coast of
Naples.

"A GUIDE FOR THE DATELESS"
With the cost of dating rising higher and higher it is no wonder
that so many of us men are turning to discus throwing. Naturally, we would prefer nuzzling warm coeds to flinging cold
disci, but who's got that kind of money? Prices being what they
are,the average man today has a simple choice: dating or eating.
Unless the average man happens to be Finster Sigafoos.
Finster came to college with the normal ambition of any
average man: he wanted to find the prettiest coed on campus
and make her his. He looked long and carefully, and at last he
found her—a tall job named Kretchma Inskip, with hair like
beaten gold.
He asked her for a date. She accepted. He appeared at her
sorority house that night,smiling, eager, and carrying a bouquet
of modestly priced flowers.
"Now then," said Kretchma, tossing the sleazy flora to a
pledge, "where are we going tonight?"
Finster was a man short on cash, but long on ideas. He had
prepared an attractive plan for this evening. "How would you
like to go out to the Ag campus and see the milking machine?",
he asked.
"Ick," she replied.
"Well, what would you like to do?" he asked.
"Come," said she,"to a funny little place I know just outside
of town."
And away they went.

Is your future up in the air?
As the communications needs of our nation
become steadily greater and more complex,
the Bell Telephone System is continuing its
pioneer work in microwave by "taking to the
air" more and more to get the word across.
To this end, Western Electric—the manufacturing arm of the Bell System—has the
monumental task of producing a large part of
the microwave transmission equipment that
knits our country together by shrinking thousands of miles into mere seconds.
In spite of its great technological strides,
the science of radio relay is a rapidly-changing
one. And new brehk-throughs and advances
are common occurrences. A case in point: our
Bell System "TH" Microwave Radio Relay.
This newest development in long-distance
telephone transmission will eventually triple
the present message-carrying capacity of existing long-haul radio relay installations. A fullscale system of 6 working and 2 protection
channels can handle 11,000 telephone messages at the same time.
To make microwave work takes a host of
special equipment and components: relay
towers, antennae, waveguides, traveling wavetubes, transistors, etc. But just as important,

it takes top-caliber people to help us broaden
our horizons into such exciting new areas as
communication by satellites!
And microwave is only part of Western
Electric's opportunity story. We have—right
now—hundreds of challenging and rewarding
positions in virtually all areas of telephony,
as well as in development and building of
defense communications and missile guidance
systems .for the Government.
So, if your future is "up in the air," you owe
it to your career to see "what's up" for you at
Western Electric.
Opportunities exist for electrical, mechanical, industrial, civil and chemical engineers, as well as physical
science, liberal arts, and business majors. For more
information, get your copy of "Western Electric and
Your Career" from your Placement Officer. Or write
College Relations, Room 6106, Western Electric Company, 195 Broadway, New York 7, N. Y. And be sure
to arrange for a Western Electric interview when the
Bell System recruiting team visits your campus.

Goucher Offers
Three Lectures
About Radiation
A series of lectures on radiation and its effects are currently being given at Goucher College.
On Februa'ry. 21 Dr. Otto E.
Landman will deliver a talk on
"The Effect of Radiation on
Genes." Dr. Landman is affiliated with the Medical Bacteriology Division of the Army
Chemical Center. The talk will
be held in Mary Fisher Lounge
at 1:30 .p.m.
"The
Use
of
Radioactive
Isotopes in Research" will be the
subject of a talk given by Dr.
Hugh Miller of the Atomic
Energy Commission. Dr. Miller
will speak in Mary Fisher
Lounge on February 26 at 1:30
p.m.
The final lecture in the series
will take place in Anna Heubeck
Lounge on March 3 at 7:00 p.m.
Dr. William L. Neumann of the
Goucher History Department will
discuss "The Military and Strategic Significance of Nuclear
Energy."

President Out of Touch
That Dr. Eisenhower, himself,
Is out of touch with the student
body, is quite evident from his
recently published report on the
University. Filled with reuttered
self praise and past glory, it presented a picture wholly foreign
to the University of the undergraduate. His proposal for dormitory advisors .was an unrealistic proposal in view of our past
experiences with them. Advisors
provide little direction, from our
experience; and the type of direction they offer is usually the
kind which the undergraduate
tries to avoid.
Rather than additional advisors or more stringent student
regulations, this undergraduate
body needs direction and organization on the levels on which
it can be satisfied. It craves
recognition in a scholar-laden
environment which seems only
to ignore it. It wants a Dr.
Morrill who can offer a challenging and inspiring program of
student activities in the nature
of the highly popular Baltimore
Symphony concerts and some of
the Levering sponsored events.
It wants a faculty willing to
offer, a varied course schedule
with more inspirational lectures.
It wants school pride and spirit
which seems suppressed everywhere.

McCollum Gains
Medicine Medal
For Research
Dr. Elmer McCollum, discoverer of Vitamin A and professor
emeritus of Bio-Chemistry at The
Johns Hopkins University, has
received the New York Academy
of Medicine Medal for his basic
research and contributions in
the field of nutrition.
The noted Hopkins biochemist's accomplishments also include the discovery of vitamin
131 and vitamin D. He is also a
founder of the Johns Hopkins
McCollum-Pratt Institute.
Dr. McCollum's latest honor
reads in part: "In recognition of
his basic research which ushered
in the era of the newer knowledge of nutrition; of his fruitful
efforts which contributed to the
eradication of deficiency diseases; of his demonstration of
the tremendous significance of
nutrition ... for the promotion
Of health and prolongation of
life; and his inflluence upon
dietary habits of man throughout the world, writing and teaching.
"
Dr. McCollum is only the 15th
Than to receive the medical medal since its formation 32 years
ago.

Geophysical Union
Names Pritchard
To Presidency
Dr. Donald W. Pritchard, director of the Chesapeake Bay
Institute of The Johns Hopkins
University, has been named
president of the American Geophysical Union. Dr. Pritchard is
scheduled to take office July 1,
and will remain in the post for
three years.
The AGU will hold its 13th
general assembly of the International Union of Geodesy and
Geophysics in Berkeley, Caliiornia, in August.
Dr. Pritchard is presently
Conducting studies of the dispersal and movement of nuclear
waste products in estuarine and
coastal environments. He has
also conducted work in the past
on the dynamics of estuarine
circulation.
He received his bachelor of
science degree in meterology at
the University of California in
1942. He received his master's
degree in Oceanography from
of
the Scripps Institution
Oceanography in 1948 and completed his doctoral degree at the
Scripps Institute in 1952. He
joined the Johns Hopkins University faculty in 1953.

CONTROL SYSTEMS:
ORDERS FROM A COMPUTER
NOW CONTROL
GIANT OIL REFINERY UNIT

Every 24 hours, the world's largest distillation unit separates
crude oil into ten different categories which end up as six
million gallons of finished products.
This involves continual monitoring of 196 instruments, followed by precise balancing of controls. To operate at peak
efficiency, control directions are changed seventy-two times
daily to compensate for a multitude of variables.
The IBM computer that recently took over this job now reads
the instruments, makes the calculations, and issues the
orders for the control changes. It is guided in its work by
75,000 instructions stored in its electronic memory.
Just a few years ago electronic control of such a complex

industrial process would have been impossible. But such is
the progress in computer systems that in the sixties it will
become commonplace.
This dramatic progress means exciting and important jobs
at IBM for the college graduate, whether in research, development, manufacturing, or programming.
If you want to find out about opportunities in any one of these
areas, you are invited to talk with the IBM representative. He
will be interviewing on your campus this year. Your placement
office can make an appointment. Or write, outlining your
background and interests, to: Mgr. of Technical Employment,
Dept. 898, IBM Corp., 590 Madison Ave., New York 22, N. Y,
